Posts.Title: Irreversible Electroporation; surgery; radiation

Posts.Content: I was having somewhat of the same problem and found that if I changed the way of doing my daily Kegel's the problem went away. After surgery I was doing them while walking. That didn't seem to help much at all, I was leaking and squirting all over the place. Then I read the sticky from Mayo and started doing them while sitting on the toilet. That helped somewhat but still was getting a squirt now and then. Especially during foreplay & during sex. Then I switched to doing them while laying down in bed on my back. For me that worked! When I go to bed I do 6 or 7 Kegel's with a 10 count, and I haven't had a problem since. No leaks & no squirts at any time, including during foreplay and sex. Bottom line is you just have to find what works best for you. Good luck!

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: All the above answers are point on. I would like to add that you should get out and get moving. Become dedicated to getting into better shape and taking better care of yourself with proper diet and exercise. I would suggest that you find a gym that has a certified trainer that works with it's members. He or she will review your past injuries and your present physical condition and get you on the right track to slowly improve yourself. My brother-in-law had similar conditions as you. Approx. a year ago he made the decision to get back on track and joined a gym with a trainer on staff. He has lost well over 100 pounds, is on a good diet and says he hasn't felt this good in years. He said he has more energy and now likes to get out and do things, where before it was sitting in front of the TV with a beer. I don't see him very often and almost didn't recognize him when I last saw him due to his weight loss. He said the trainer was very thorough and started him out slowly with the exercise that fitted his needs. He also was referred by his doctor to a dietitian who helped him with his diet. Good luck with your journey.

Posts.Title: Day 5 after Surgery

Posts.Content: I'm sure everyone responds differently. As for my experience I went in at 5 AM and was up and waking the hallways of the hospital by noon the same day. I had no pain, no discomfort really, and was taking no pain meds. I was released after 3 days. I would have been released on the second day, but I am on blood thinner, so they kept me one more just to make sure I was doing all right. On the release day they took the drain tube out and that was a bit of a jolt, not really painful, just a weird feeling. I also had the catheter removed on the 3rd day, which was more of a relief than any pain involved. I walked approx. 3 to 5 miles a day prior to going in and was doing Kegals as instructed. For that matter I still do Kegals 3 times a week and walk or ride a bicycle everyday. They used super glue for all the holes left by the robot, so no stitches. I have no regret at all for having the prostate removed when I did. Had a great surgeon at an excellent hospital and no complications.

Posts.Title: Climacturia? Anyone else?

Posts.Content: I was on Viagra and tried to live with the side effects for about 6 months. I finally quit taking it. According to the doctor it stays in the system approx. 4 hours. However, the effects sure lasted a lot longer. The upset stomach lasted for 12 or more hours and that included heartburn. My sinus felt as if they were going to make my head explode and I had blurry vision that would last 4 to 6 hours after taking the Viagra. I was taking 50mg on Monday and Wednesday and 100mg on Friday. I tried taking it at night and it would keep me awake, and I also tried taking it during the day or in the morning and the effects were always the same. I have not tried Cialis and am not going to. So far after stopping the Viagra I have been able to get a satisfying erection without using any meds so the Viagra is not needed.

Posts.Title: Stress leads to additional problems. My Story as a warning

Posts.Content: We have insurance and this is what recently happened to us recently; and yes we have insurance and Medicare. My wife was sent for an x-ray. She went to a facility that was on our approved insurance list. We paid the required co-pay and did not receive any more billing from the facility that provided the x-ray. HOWEVER, the radiologist that read the x-ray does not accept any insurance plans or Medicare. So we had to pay him separately out of pocket. The facility advised they contract out to independents and have no control over what they charge. I called our insurance company and they advised that we will see more of this type of practice as the new health care system kicks in.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Six years ago when I became eligible for Medicare, I chose "Medicare Advantage" and in that category I chose an HMO type plan that has many doctors, hospitals and clinics in The Group that I can choose from..I have suffered no nasty billing surprises. I pay the published copay and that's that..The downside is I must stay in my group which is basically the entire Denver area..If you like to travel, this type of insurance puts you at a disadvantage because it will not pay if you are outside your area...You can buy a plan that offers nationwide coverage but it's considerably more expensive.. Fairwind, We have Aetna Medicare Advantage plan provided by my employer retirement plan and we can go to anyone we want to. They do have a preferred list and we do try and stay within that list. But we can travel without a problem. We just enter a zip code for where we are and a list comes right up.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to hear that you had such pain & problems after surgery. My case was the complete opposite. I had no pain what so ever, & never took anything for pain. I walked a lot around the hospital corridors right after I got back to my room. I was in the hospital 3 days and the only reason they kept me was to get my Coumiden level back to where it should be. I did have some swelling and was black and blue but that all went away in approx. 2 to 3 weeks. So not every one has your experience, but it is good to relate the experience to give a new comer some incite as to what they might expect. Hope you continue to do well.

Posts.Title: First Week Journal - Days 1 to 3, post robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: First and foremost make sure you consider all remedies. Listen to the doctors and always get a second opinion. I went with robotic and have not looked back and have no regrets. But that was mine and my wife's decision. I was about your age and in pretty good health, and I still am. After the operation I needed no assistance of any kind. I was able to go up and down stairs, drive or do pretty much what I wanted to do within reason. But we all respond differently. I wish you luck with your decision. I was told that even if you have radiation and later still have a problem it is very difficult to have the prostate removed. For me, radiation was not an option.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: At this point I have nothing bad to say. Surgery scars are almost gone, just little spots now. All bruising is gone. I do have a little leakage going on yet, but mostly in the late afternoon or evening. I know, I should stay away from caffeine! Even went to Walmart and made it in and out without any leakage! I am still walking 2 to 3 times a day at about a mile or better each time out. Also still doing the Kegels. Erection's are coming back and at this point I would say nearly back to normal. I would say the penis is more sensitive than before the surgery. Maybe that is just me, I am not sure. I am on Viagra 3 times a week, 100 mg on Monday and 50 mg on Wednesday and Friday, and I would say it helps in the erection department. Also still using the pump and not sure if that is doing any good or not.

Posts.Title: 5 Weeks after Da-Vinci

Posts.Content: First and foremost make sure you consider all remedies. Listen to the doctors and always get a second opinion. I went with robotic and have not looked back and have no regrets. But that was mine and my wife's decision. I was about your age and in pretty good health, and I still am. After the operation I needed no assistance of any kind. I was able to go up and down stairs, drive or do pretty much what I wanted to do within reason. But we all respond differently. I wish you luck with your decision. I was told that even if you have radiation and later still have a problem it is very difficult to have the prostate removed. For me, radiation was not an option.

Posts.Title: A little off topic....

Posts.Content: We have insurance and this is what recently happened to us recently; and yes we have insurance and Medicare. My wife was sent for an x-ray. She went to a facility that was on our approved insurance list. We paid the required co-pay and did not receive any more billing from the facility that provided the x-ray. HOWEVER, the radiologist that read the x-ray does not accept any insurance plans or Medicare. So we had to pay him separately out of pocket. The facility advised they contract out to independents and have no control over what they charge. I called our insurance company and they advised that we will see more of this type of practice as the new health care system kicks in.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Six years ago when I became eligible for Medicare, I chose "Medicare Advantage" and in that category I chose an HMO type plan that has many doctors, hospitals and clinics in The Group that I can choose from..I have suffered no nasty billing surprises. I pay the published copay and that's that..The downside is I must stay in my group which is basically the entire Denver area..If you like to travel, this type of insurance puts you at a disadvantage because it will not pay if you are outside your area...You can buy a plan that offers nationwide coverage but it's considerably more expensive.. Fairwind, We have Aetna Medicare Advantage plan provided by my employer retirement plan and we can go to anyone we want to. They do have a preferred list and we do try and stay within that list. But we can travel without a problem. We just enter a zip code for where we are and a list comes right up.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Pathology Billing

Posts.Content: I am 2 years past the DaVinci surgery with Dr. Patel. For me it was a good experience. In the past I had hernia surgery 4 different times and also I am on Coumadin for blood clots in my legs. Dr. Patel took every precaution in my opinion. I had to see 2 other surgeons prior to Dr. Patel doing his thing. The first was to check for scaring and adhesion's from the past hernia surgeries. Actually, that surgeon was the first to start with the robot to clean up all the adhesion's from those past hernia surgeries. He also fixed another hernia that hadn't popped up yet. Then the other doc was a specialist that monitored my Coumadin and made sure it would not be a problem prior, during, and after the DaVinci. With all bases covered I went in for surgery about 6AM and was up walking the hallways by noon. I had no pain and took no pain meds. I did have to stay in the hospital a couple of more days than usual until they got my blood level back to where they wanted it. As for the hospital, I have been in 4 different hospitals in my life, and Celebration Hospital was great. The nurses, the aides, everyone there treated us (my wife was with me) great. You can ask Dr. Patel or anyone on his staff anything. They don't hesitate to answer any question you have. If I had to do it over, I would not change a thing. Good luck on what ever you decide. Write down all your questions you have and go through them when you meet with Dr. Patel and his staff, if you decide to use him. Since I have been there, if you have any questions for me don't hesitate to ask.

Posts.Title: Are You Just Looking Could YOU have ProstateCancer

Posts.Content: Brian G Ask your doctor (surgeon) what to do as far as the masturbation goes. Believe me they have been asked worse questions than that. Mine told me that after surgery to wait at least 4 weeks, then it was up to me if I wanted to do that or not. He said it would not hurt a thing and does help with blood flow. My nerves were spared, so that may have made some difference in his reply. As far as meds go, I had to argue and fight with my prescription provider to get Viagra approved for one year and after that they will no longer cover. My surgeon told me if after a year I still need Viagra that they have a contact in Canada that has the generic Viagra at a very reasonable price. He said he would be happy to write the script if I needed it. Remember that time heals, so hang in there.

Posts.Title: The incidence of second primary cancer

Posts.Content: New here and newly diagnosed with prostate cancer. Over the past couple of years my PSA was holding faily steady around 2.2 to 2.4. Then suddenly it went up to 3.5, 6 months later 5.7. I was sent for a biopsy and my score was T2 b/c and Gleason of 7. I have chosen to have a robotic prostatectomy at Florida Celebration Hospital, and the Surgeon Dr. Vipul Patel. My question here has anyone used this hospital and surgeon? Were you satisfied with the results? Surgeon / patient experience?
Posts.Title: First Post

Posts.Content: Well, I will turn 66 in a few months. Overall my physical condition is very good. Both the family doctor and urologist advised I was an excellent subject for the surgery. According to Dr. Patel's web site he has performed over 5000 robotic prostatectomy's. When I spoke with his secretary for an appointment to see him, she said he is now over 6000. The only reason I ended up at a urologist to begin with was because when my family doctor checked my PSA it was going up rather quickly. I see on the 28th for consultation and will know more then.
Posts.Title: First Post

Posts.Content: He was highly recommended by my urologist, as well as the hospital. If you do a search for "Florida Celebration Hospital, go to mens health, then prostate cancer you will find all sorts of info about him. I also Googled his name and came up with some more info. Typical of a surgeon, he does not have a lot of bedside manner, but appears that he is good at what he does.
Posts.Title: First Post

Posts.Content: New here and newly diagnosed with prostate cancer. Over the past couple of years my PSA was holding faily steady around 2.2 to 2.4. Then suddenly it went up to 3.5, 6 months later 5.7. I was sent for a biopsy and my score was T2 b/c and Gleason of 7. I have chosen to have a robotic prostatectomy at Florida Celebration Hospital, and the Surgeon Dr. Vipul Patel. My question here has anyone used this hospital and surgeon? Were you satisfied with the results? Surgeon / patient experience?

Posts.Title: Come on Man!!

Posts.Content: masbirdies, I also had Dr. Patel. During the 8 week after the surgery interview my wife and I are sitting there going over questions and answers with Dr. Patel. Dr. Patel asked how often we were having sexual intercourse and after a brief discussion he said for a healthy sex life we should be having intercourse no less than twice a week or more. My wife almost fell off her chair! She didn't say anything then, but on the way home in the car she did say don't count on getting it twice a week anytime in the near future. She said she wondered if (Dr. Patel) was getting it twice or more a week.

Posts.Title: Got 8 week post surgery follow-up and first PSA score today.....

Posts.Content: I hope your father does continue to improve. The question is though, is he doing his Kegel's. They need to be done almost on a daily basis. I know I did them regularly following the "sticky" note above from Mayo Clinic on how to do them. Then I quit doing them for a couple of weeks and the incontinence came back. The Kegels can be done several ways, one according to the Mayo Clinic, but I found laying on my back in bed has worked the best for me. I do them every night after going to bed and I have been dry since. Good luck also with your health. Good advice from Michael F in the above post.
